oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Effects of Exercise on Reproduction m• Budgerigars
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Welle, Kenneth R.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the National Research Council'sGuide for the Care and Use ofLaboratory Animals (1972), exercise isdefined as "any physical activity:' Thepurpose of this research is to determinethe effect of physical activity on thereproductive system.The need for exercise to maintaingood general health has been describedfor several animals including rats (Farris,1954), rabbits (Sawin, 1954), opossums(Farris, 1954), and monkeys (Wagnen,1954), although Pope indicates that it isnot necessary in lizards (1954). Dawsonstates that female cats ''do not becomesexually receptive when confined tocages,'' and that males should also beallowed ''considerable freedom ofmovement" (1954).The budgerigar (Melopsittacusundulatus) was chosen for theexperiment since it is a psittacine andclosely related to all parrot-like birds.Some parrot-like birds are difficult tobreed and observations from budgerigarsmay be cautiously applied to other psittacines.
